title: Does tempo equal offense success in the Big Ten?
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors




Code
logs24 <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs24.csv")


Rows: 1717 Columns: 79
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (11): Location, Opponent, Result, OT, Bowl.x, TeamURL, Outcome, Bowl.y,...
dbl  (64): Rk, Gtm, Points, PointsOpp, PassCmp, PassAtt, PassPct, PassYds, P...
lgl   (3): Score, TeamScore, OpponentScore
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Code
logs25 <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs25.csv")


Rows: 711 Columns: 77
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (9): Location, Opponent, Result, OT, TeamURL, Outcome, Team, Conferenc...
dbl  (64): Rk, Gtm, Points, PointsOpp, PassCmp, PassAtt, PassPct, PassYds, P...
lgl   (3): Score, TeamScore, OpponentScore
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Here I created a file set that filtered for just the Big Ten teams, filtering the teams in the conference. Then we took the nunmber of total plays divided by the amount of games that the teams played in.


Code
bigten24 <- logs24 |>
  filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference")

bigten25 <- logs25 |>
  filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference")




Code
avg_plays_24 <- bigten24 |>
  group_by(Team) |>
  summarize(avg_plays = mean(TotalPlays, na.rm = TRUE)) |>
  mutate(season = "2024")

avg_plays_25 <- bigten25 |>
  group_by(Team) |>
  summarize(avg_plays = mean(TotalPlays, na.rm = TRUE)) |>
  mutate(season = "2025")


Sometimes, team’s offenses run a lot of plays because they want to speed up the pace of the game. But other times, it’s because their defense is unable to get any stops. Ocassionaly, it’s both. That’s what happened with 2024 Maryland, who had one of the worst passing defenses in the Big Ten, allowing opponents to throw for over 300 yards per game in a majority of its Big Ten contests. The Terps’ offense was constantly on the field and trying to play catch up, which led to them running the most amunt of plays.


Code
ggplot(avg_plays_24, aes(x = reorder(Team, avg_plays), y = avg_plays)) +
  geom_col(fill = "#1f77b4") +
  coord_flip() +
 labs(title = "Maryland football finished 4-8.", subtitle = "It still ran the most offensive plays in the Big Ten",
    x = "Team",
    y = "Average Offensive Plays"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()









But this season, we’ve seen some drastic shifts in the conference. Ohio State, who has some of the most offensive firepower in the nation, runs the least amount of plays in the Big Ten. That’s most likely due to the Buckeyes’ blowing out several teams, but they also have had one of the nation’s best defenses, and this is a somewhat troubling sign for Ohio State’s future. One other takeaway: teams with strong and older quarterbacks tend to run more plays. Seven of the top eight teams have either old quarterbacks or a strong true freshman signal-caller in the case of Maryland and Malik Washington.


Code
ggplot(avg_plays_25, aes(x = reorder(Team, avg_plays), y = avg_plays)) +
  geom_col(fill = "#ff7f0e") +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    title = "Ohio State's offense is dominant despite not running plays",
    x = "Team",
    y = "Average Offensive Plays"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()
